[[Promiscuity]] tends to be frowned upon by many societies, expecting most members to have [[Committed relationship|committed, long-term relationships]] with single partners.
Most societies have historically been more critical of women's promiscuity than of [[heterosexual]] men's. Among women, as well as men, inclination for sex outside committed relationships is correlated with a high [[libido]],<ref name="Baumeister" /> but social and cultural factors have also been observed to influence sexual behavior and opinion.<ref name="Lippa2009" /><ref name="Regan&Atkins2006" />
== Cause == {{See also|Hormones and sexual motivation|Sexual desire#Sex differences in sexual desire|Libido#Factors}}
Studies have related [[sociosexual orientation]] to [[sex drive]], especially in women, where the higher the sex drive the less restricted the sociosexual orientation, or interest in sex outside [[committed relationship]]s.<ref name="Baumeister">{{cite journal|last1=Baumeister |first1=RF |title=Gender and erotic plasticity: Sociocultural influences on the sex drive |doi=10.1080/14681990410001691343 |journal=Sexual and Relationship Therapy |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=133–139 |year=2004}}</ref> Nevertheless, pertaining to the [[nature and nurture]] debate, there is some data emphasizing cultural factors, more so for women than for men.<ref name="Lippa2009">{{Cite journal | last1 = Lippa | first1 = R. A. | title = Sex Differences in Sex Drive, Sociosexuality, and Height across 53 Nations: Testing Evolutionary and Social Structural Theories | doi = 10.1007/s10508-007-9242-8 | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 38 | issue = 5 | pages = 631–651 | year = 2007 | pmid = 17975724| pmc = }}</ref><ref name="Regan&Atkins2006">{{cite journal|last1=Regan |first1=PC |last2=Atkins |first2=L |year=2006 |title=Sex Differences and Similarities in Frequency and Intensity of Sexual Desire |journal=Social Behavior & Personality: an International Journal |volume=34 |issue=1 |pages=95–101 |doi=10.2224/sbp.2006.34.1.95}}</ref> One review assessed that sociosexuality was affected almost equally by [[heredity]] and environment unshared with siblings; shared environment had relatively little effect.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bailey |first1=JM |last2=Kirk |first2=KM |last3=Zhu |first3=G |last4=Dunne |first4=MP |last5=Martin |first5=NG |url=https://genepi.qimr.edu.au/contents/p/staff/CV262Bailey_UQ_Copy.pdf |format=PDF |title=Do Individual Differences in Sociosexuality Represent Genetic or Environmentally Contingent Strategies? Evidence From the Australian Twin Registry |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |year=2000 |volume=78 |issue=3 |pages=537–545. 0022–3514/00/S5.00 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.78.3.537}}</ref>
Men tend to have higher sociosexuality scores and be more unrestricted than women across a variety of cultures.<ref name="FirstSchmitt">{{cite journal|last1=Schmitt |first1=DP |year=2005 |title=Sociosexuality from Argentina to Zimbabwe: A 48-nation study of sex, culture, and strategies of human mating |journal=Behavioral and Brain Sciences |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=247–311 |doi=10.1017/S0140525X05000051 |pmid=16201459}}</ref><ref name="Schmitt">{{cite journal|last1=Schmitt |first1=DP |year=2007 |title=Sexual strategies across sexual orientations: How personality traits and culture relate to sociosexuality among gays, lesbians, bisexuals, and heterosexuals |journal=Journal of Psychology and Human Sexuality |volume=18 |issue=2–3 |pages=183–214 |doi=10.1300/J056v18n02_06}}</ref> However, there is more variability in scores within each gender than between men and women, indicating that although the average man is less restricted than the average woman, individuals may vary in sociosexual orientation regardless of gender.<ref name="Gangestad">{{cite journal|last1=Gangestad |first1=SW |last2=Simpson |first2=JA |year=2000 |title=The evolution of human mating: Trade-offs and strategic pluralism |journal=Behavioral and Brain Sciences |volume=23 |issue=4 |pages=573–587 |doi=10.1017/S0140525X0000337X |pmid=11301543|url=http://www2.psych.ubc.ca/~schaller/Psyc591Readings/GangestadSimpson2000.pdf}}</ref>
=== Psychology ===
Contrary to popular belief, [[Body image|body esteem]] in women showed a significant positive correlation with sociosexual unrestrictedness.<ref name="predict" /> So did [[Waist–hip ratio|hip-to-waist ratio]] and two measures of [[virilization]].<ref name="predict" /> Finally, still in the same study, [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] consumption correlated, too, but it is unclear whether the latter promoted the former or vice versa, or if a third variable was at play.<ref name="predict">{{cite journal|last=Clard |first=AP |url=http://seis.bris.ac.uk/~psapc/pdfs/Clark%282004%29.pdf |format=PDF |title=Self-perceived attractiveness and masculinization predict women's sociosexuality |journal=Evolution and Human Behavior |volume=25 |issue=2 |year=2004 |pages=113–124 |doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(03)00085-0 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121130054024/http://seis.bris.ac.uk/~psapc/pdfs/Clark%282004%29.pdf |archivedate=2012-11-30 |df= }}</ref>
[[Bisexuality|Bisexual]] women tend to be less restricted in their sociosexual attitudes than both homo- and heterosexual women. In sociosexual behavior also, bisexual women reported being more unrestricted, followed by homo- and then heterosexual women.<ref name="Schmitt" />
[[Power (social and political)|Social power]] has been popularly associated with sexual [[wiktionary:infidelity|infidelity]] among men; experimental psychologists have linked power with sexual infidelity among women also. A Dutch study involving a large survey of 1,561 professionals, concluded that "The relationship between power and infidelity was the same for women as for men, and for the same reason. These findings suggest that the common assumption (and often-found effect) that women are less likely than men to engage in infidelity is, at least partially, a reflection of traditional gender-based differences in power that exist in society."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lammers |first1=J |last2=Stoker |first2=JI |last3=Jordan |first3=J |last4=Pollmann |first4=MMH |last5=Stapel |first5=DA |year=2011 |url=http://pss.sagepub.com/content/22/9/1191.short |title=Power increases infidelity among men and women |journal=Psychological Science |doi=10.1177/0956797611416252 |volume=22 |issue=9 |pages=1191–7 |pmid=21771963}}</ref>
[[Church (building)|Church]]-attending women score lower on promiscuity than other women, while men appear to lack this correlation.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fagan |first1=PF |last2=Nicholas |first2=Z |url=https://downloads.frc.org/EF/EF11L30.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Benefits of Religious Attendance |journal=Marri Research |date=December 14, 2011 }}</ref>
A 2010 study published in ''[[Journal of Marriage and Family]]'' found that there was a correlation between female pre-marital promiscuity and higher rates of divorce. The research, conducted by Jay Teachman, found that women with 16 or more sexual partners prior to marriage had an 80% rate of subsequent divorce.<ref>Teachman, Jay, "[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1741-3737.2003.00444.x/abstract Premarital Sex, Premarital Cohabitation, and the Risk of Subsequent. Marital Dissolution Among Women]", ''[[Journal of Marriage and Family]]'', September 2010</ref>
=== Biology ===
Men and women leading [[polyandrous]] lifestyles have higher levels of [[testosterone]]. However, it is unclear whether higher levels of testosterone cause increased sex drive and in turn multiple partners or whether sexual activity with multiple partners causes the increase in testosterone.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Van Anders |first1=SM |last2=Hamilton |first2=LD |last3=Watson |first3=NV |title=Multiple partners are associated with higher testosterone in North American men and women |journal=Hormones and Behavior |volume=51 |issue=3 |pages=454–459 |year=2007 |doi=10.1016/j.yhbeh.2007.01.002 |pmid=17316638}}</ref> Sociosexuality in women is positively correlated with two measures of [[prenatal]] exposure to [[androgens]]—right [[digit ratio]], and scores on the [[Mental rotation#Vandenburg and Kuse|Vandenberg Mental Rotation test]]—providing some limited support to the [[virilization]] hypothesis of female promiscuity<ref name="predict" /> (see also [[Prenatal hormones and sexual orientation]]). The aforementioned hypothesis is not at all mutually exclusive with other hypotheses.
Libido is correlated with the [[menstrual cycle]] so that many women experience an increase in sexual desire several days immediately before [[ovulation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bullivant |first1=SB |last2=Sellergren |first2=SA |last3=Stern |first3=Kathleen |title=Women's sexual experience during the menstrual cycle: identification of the sexual phase by noninvasive measurement of luteinizing hormone |journal=Journal of Sex Research |date=February 2004 |volume=41 |issue=1 |pages=82–93 (in online article, see pp.14–15, 18–22) |url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2372/is_1_41/ai_n6032944 |pmid=15216427 |doi=10.1080/00224490409552216 |last4=Spencer |first4=Natasha A. |last5=Jacob |first5=Suma |last6=Mennella |first6=Julie A. |last7=McClintock |first7=Martha K. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070923001735/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2372/is_1_41/ai_n6032944 |archivedate=2007-09-23 |df= }}</ref> Testosterone levels rise gradually from about the 24th day of a woman's menstrual cycle until ovulation on about the 14th day of the next cycle.<ref>{{cite book|title=28 Days: What Your Cycle Reveals about Your Love Life, Moods, and Potential |last=Lichterman |first=Gabrielle |isbn=978-1-59337-345-0}}{{incomplete short citation|date=January 2014}}</ref> During the high-testosterone period before ovulation, a woman typically feels more attracted to masculine facial features and is more likely to pursue short-term mating.
It is common for sex drive to diminish dramatically after [[menopause]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sarrel |first=PM |title=Psychosexual effects of menopause: role of androgens |journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology |volume=180 |issue=3 Pt 2 |pages=S319–24 |year=1999 |pmid=10076172 |doi=10.1016/S0002-9378(99)70727-1}}</ref> A number of studies, including [[Alfred Kinsey]]'s, have concluded that the average age group in which women are the most active sexually is their mid-thirties, one study liberally estimating 27-45 as the limits of the age group (the average man peaks earlier).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Easton |first1=JA |last2=Confer |first2=JC |last3=Goetz |first3=CD |last4=Buss |first4=DM |url=http://homepage.psy.utexas.edu/homepage/students/easton/PAID_RE_final.pdf |format=PDF |title=Reproduction expediting: Sexual motivations, fantasies, and the ticking biological clock |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=49 |issue=5 |year=2010 |pages=516–520 |place=The University of Texas at Austin |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2010.05.018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616102925/http://homepage.psy.utexas.edu/homepage/students/easton/PAID_RE_final.pdf |archivedate=2013-06-16 |df= }}</ref> Women in this age group typically report having sexual fantasies greater in number and intensity, engaging in sexual activity more frequently, and being more interested in casual sex.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cloud |first=John |title=The Science of Cougar Sex: Why Older Women Lust |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2007422,00.html |magazine=Time Magazine |date=July 9, 2010}}</ref>
One study in [[sexual antagonism]] suggested a possible genetic link between female [[Androphilia|androphilic]] promiscuity and [[Homosexuality|male androphilia]]: [[Samoa]]n tribal women exhibited a correlation between reproductive output and the likeliness of having androphilic grandsons, though not nephews (see also [[Fa'afafine]]).<ref name="fa'afafine">{{cite journal|last1=VanderLaan |first1=DP |last2=Forrester |first2=DL |last3=Petterson |first3=LJ |last4=Vasey |first4=PL |year=2012 |title=''Offspring Production among the Extended Relatives of Samoan Men and ''Fa'afafine |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0036088 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=4 |page=e36088 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0036088 |editor1-last=Vitzthum |editor1-first=Virginia J|bibcode = 2012PLoSO...736088V |pmid=22558342 |pmc=3338633}}</ref>
Rate of molecular evolution of the seminal protein gene [[SEMG2]] correlates with levels of female promiscuity.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dorus |first1=S |last2=Evans |first2=PD |last3=Wyckoff |first3=GJ |last4=Choi |first4=SS |last5=Lahn |first5=BT |title=Rate of molecular evolution of the seminal protein gene SEMG2 correlates with levels of female promiscuity |journal=Nat. Genet. |volume=36 |issue=12 |pages=1326–9 |year=2005 |pmid=15531881 |doi=10.1038/ng1471}}</ref>
[[File:Bonobo cincyzoo.jpg|thumb|left|200px|[[Bonobo]]s treat sexual activity as a very versatile form of [[social interaction]], with purposes ranging from stress reduction to conflict resolution. Females tend to collectively dominate males by forming alliances and use sexuality to control males.]]
Pathological overactivity of the [[dopaminergic]] [[mesolimbic pathway]] in the brain—forming either psychiatrically, during [[mania]],<ref name="mania">{{cite journal|last=Silverstone |first=T |title=Dopamine in manic depressive illness. A pharmacological synthesis |journal=Journal of Affective Disorders |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=225–31 |year=1985 |pmid=2862169 |doi=10.1016/0165-0327(85)90020-5}}</ref> or pharmacologically, as a side effect of [[dopamine agonist]]s, specifically [[Dopamine receptor D3|D<sub>3</sub>]]-preferring agonists<ref name="D3I">{{cite web|url=https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/uspdi/203739.html |title=MedlinePlus Drug Information: Pramipexole (Systemic) |accessdate=2006-09-27 |publisher=[[United States National Library of Medicine]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060926023858/https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginfo/uspdi/203739.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate=2006-09-26}}</ref><ref name="D3II">{{cite journal|last=Boyd |first=Alan |year=1995 |title=Bromocriptine and psychosis: A literature review |journal=Psychiatric Quarterly |volume=66 |issue=1 |pages=87–95 |doi=10.1007/BF02238717 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/y42v466374524k1m/ |accessdate=2008-09-06 |pmid=7701022}}</ref>—is associated with various [[addiction]]s<ref name="fn5">{{cite journal|last1=Arias-Carrión |first1=O |last2=Pöppel |first2=E |title=Dopamine, learning and reward-seeking behavior |journal=Acta Neurobiol Exp |volume=67 |issue=4 |pages=481–488 |year=2007}}</ref><ref name="NestlerArticle">{{cite journal|last=Nestler |first=Eric J. |place=Department of Psychiatry and Center for Basic Neuroscience, The University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center |title=Is There A Common Molecular Pathway For Addiction? |doi=10.1038/nn1578 |journal=Nature Neuroscience |volume=8 |issue=11 |pages=1445–1449 |year=2005 |url=http://dept.wofford.edu/neuroscience/NeuroSeminar/pdfSpring2006/a7.pdf |pmid=16251986}}</ref> and has been shown to result among some subjects of either sex in overindulgent, sometimes [[hypersexual]], behavior.<ref name="mania" /><ref name="D3I" /><ref name="D3II" />
Polyandrous mating is positively correlated with [[testicle]]-to-body weight across bushcricket [[Taxon|taxa]] (see [[Sperm competition]]).<ref>{{open access}} {{cite journal|last1=Vahed |first1=K |last2=Parker |first2=DJ |last3=Gilbert |first3=JDJ |url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/early/2010/10/21/rsbl.2010.0840.full |title=Larger testes are associated with a higher level of polyandry, but a smaller ejaculate volume, across bushcricket species (Tettigoniidae) |journal=Biology Letters |date=November 10, 2010 |pmid=21068028 |doi=10.1098/rsbl.2010.0840 |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=261–4 |pmc=3061181}}</ref> Human testicles, relative to body weight, are lighter than those of the [[chimpanzee]] genus (''Pan'') but heavier than those of [[gorilla]]s (''Gorilla'') and [[orangutan]]s (''Pongo'').<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Harcourt |first1=AH |last2=Harvey |first2=PH |last3=Larson |first3=SG |last4=Short |first4=RV |year=1981 |title=Testis weight, body weight and breeding system in primates |journal=Nature |volume=293 |pages=55–57 |bibcode=1981Natur.293...55H |doi=10.1038/293055a0 |pmid=7266658 |issue=5827}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shackelford |first1=TK |last2=Goetz |first2=AT |doi=10.1111/j.1467-8721.2007.00473.x |title=Adaptation to Sperm Competition in Humans |journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science |volume=16 |pages=47–50 |year=2007}}</ref> The [[bonobo]] chimpanzee species (''Pan paniscus'') has heavier testicles than the [[common chimpanzee]] species (''Pan troglodytes''). It is yet unclear whether the rule is as applicable within species as it is across species—that is, whether it is applicable across races—but according to a study by [[J. Philippe Rushton]], [[Caucasoid]] averages (21 g) are about twice as heavier as the [[Oriental]] standard (9 g).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rushton |first=JP |url=http://www.charlesdarwinresearch.org/Race_Evolution_Behavior.pdf |format=PDF |title=Race, Evolution, and Behavior: A Life History Perspective |year=2000 |edition=2nd special abridged |place=University of Western Ontario |page=19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030409145530/http://www.charlesdarwinresearch.org/Race_Evolution_Behavior.pdf |archivedate=2003-04-09}}</ref>
==== Evolution ==== {{See also|Promiscuity#Evolution|Polyandry#Polyandry in zoology|Bateman's principle#Females can be promiscuous|Sperm competition|Female sperm storage|Heteropaternal superfecundation|Concealed ovulation|Eusociality}}
[[Bateman's principle]] implies that females are choosy because there is little evolutionary advantage for them to mate with multiple males. However, observation of many species, from [[rabbit]]s to [[tephritidae|fruit flies]], has shown that females have more offspring if they mate with a larger number of males. This seemingly contradicts Bateman's theory, specifically his conclusion that "while males had more children the more partners they mated with, females did not."<ref>{{cite book|last=Judson |first=Olivia |author-link=Olivia Judson |title=Dr. Tatiana's Sex Advice To All Creation |place=New York |publisher=Metropolitan Books |year=2002 |isbn=0-8050-6331-5 |pages=11–13}}</ref> Exceptions to Bateman's principle abound, as do hypotheses explaining the evolution of female promiscuity. Females in fact have a lot to gain, depending on the species (see [[Bateman's principle#Females can be promiscuous|here]]).
Many species once thought monogamous, including such birds as [[swan]]s, are now known to engage in [[Promiscuity#Extra-pair copulation in non-humans|extra-pair copulations]].
[[Thierry Lodé]] found possible evolutionary explanations for [[polyandry]] relating to [[sexual conflict]], including mate competition and [[inbreeding avoidance]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Lodé |first=Thierry |authorlink=Thierry Lodé |url=http://formes-symboliques.org/IMG/pdf/doc-198.pdf |format=PDF |title=La guerre des sexes chez les animaux |place=Paris |editor1-last=Jacob |editor1-first=O. |year=2006 |isbn=2-7381-1901-8 |language=French}}</ref> The following list is incomplete. *It is easier to ensure reproductive success (i.e., it is more likely that the female will have offspring). *Females may be encouraging [[sperm competition]] between males post-copulation. *Multiple sperm lines may confer more variation in traits to female's offspring. *In groups of eusocial taxa, such as [[beehives]], a single female or caste produces offspring while the other organisms cooperate in caring for the young. Bees from different sperm lines excel at different roles within a single hive, benefiting the health of the hive as a whole. *In [[tortoise]], for example, as a result of clutches with greater variation in paternal genes and increased sperm competition, females can maximize both the genetic quality and number of offspring.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moon |first1=J |last2=McCoy |first2=E |last3=Mushinsky |first3=H |last4=Karl |first4=S |year=2006 |title=Multiple paternity and breeding system in the gopher tortoise, Gopherus polyphemus |journal=The Journal of Heredity |volume=97 |pages=150–157 |doi=10.1093/jhered/esj017 |pmid=16489146 |issue=2}}</ref> *Those female [[guppies]] who mated with a greater number of males in a given cycle, were more likely to bear sons, which in turn had more capacity for reproductive output.<ref>{{cite web|last=Amorim |first=Catarina |url=http://www.science20.com/catarina_amorim/how_female_promiscuity_can_be_smart_move_evolution-95169 |title=How Female Promiscuity Can Be The Smart Move In Evolution |publisher=Science 2.0 |date=October 14, 2012}}</ref> *Females may receive food offerings from prospective mates inciting copulation. *A female may pursue extra-pair copulation more during fertile periods of her [[menstrual cycle]] to conceive from a male with high-quality genes (see [[Sexy son hypothesis]]) while relying on resources and paternal investment from her social mate. *Offspring paternity is unknown and this can be beneficial in encouraging [[paternal care]] and discouraging [[infanticide]] by males.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Klemme |first1=I |last2=Ylönen |first2=H |url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/6/1/24.full |title=Polyandry enhances offspring survival in an infanticidal species |date=23 February 2010 |doi=10.1098/rsbl.2009.0500 |journal=Biology Letters |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=24–26 |pmid=19675002 |pmc=2817239}}</ref> *Female extra-pair mating behavior may evolve via indirect selection on males.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forstmeier |first1=W |last2=Martin |first2=K |last3=Bolund |first3=E |last4=Schielzeth |first4=H |last5=Kempenaers |first5=B |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/26/10608.full |title=Female extrapair mating behavior can evolve via indirect selection on males |date=June 13, 2011 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1103195108 |journal=[[PNAS]] |origyear=Published in print on June 28, 2011 |volume=108 |issue=26 |pages=10608–10613|bibcode = 2011PNAS..10810608F |pmid=21670288 |pmc=3127899}}</ref>
== Society and culture ==
[[Evolutionary psychologist]]s have theorized that taboos against female promiscuity evolved on the basis of [[Non-paternity event|paternity anxiety]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilson |first1=Margo |last2=Daly |first2=Martin |url=http://psych.mcmaster.ca/dalywilson/themanwho.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Chattel |year=1992 |place=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref> [[DNA test]]s being yet to be invented, it was impossible to accurately determine paternity, unlike maternity. A male risked spending [[paternal investment]] on offspring who carried genetic material of another male rather than of his own. Evolutionarily, this translated into [[sexual jealousy]] and complex preventive customs (e.g., [[female genital mutilation]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs241/en/index.html |title=Female genital mutilation |publisher=World Health Organization |date=February 2010}}</ref> [[menstrual taboos]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Strassman |first=BI |year=1992 |title=The function of menstrual taboos among the Dogon: defense against cuckoldry? |journal=Human Nature |volume=3 |pages=89–131 |doi=10.1007/BF02692249 |issue=2}}</ref>).
=== Pre-Modern ===
Female promiscuity is a recurring theme in mythologies and religions. In the Middle East, [[sacred prostitution]], usually in honor of Goddess [[Astarte]], had been prevalent before the 4th century when Emperor [[Constantine I]] attempted to replace pagan traditions with [[Christianity]].<ref name="3.55">[[Eusebius]], ''Life of Constantine'', {{cite web|url=http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iv.vi.iii.lv.html |title=3.55}} and {{cite web|url=http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf201.iv.vi.iii.lviii.html |title=3.58}}</ref> In [[Greek mythology]], [[nymph]]s are portrayed as dangerous nature spirits sexually uninhibited with humans; hence, the [[Victorian era|Victorian]] medical term ''[[Wiktionary:nymphomania|nymphomania]]''. [[Imperial Rome]] is popularly seen as being sexually profligate,<ref>Beert C. Verstraete and Vernon Provencal, introduction to ''Same-Sex Desire and Love in Greco-Roman Antiquity and in the Classical Tradition'' (Haworth Press, 2005), p. 5. For an extended discussion of how the modern perception of Roman sexual decadence can be traced to early [[Christian polemic]], see Alastair J.L. Blanshard, "Roman Vice," in ''Sex: Vice and Love from Antiquity to Modernity'' (Wiley-Blackwell, 2010), pp. 1–88.</ref><ref>Catharine Edwards, ''The Politics of Immorality in Ancient Rome'' (Cambridge University Press, 1993), p. 65.</ref> and certain Roman empresses—such as [[Theodora I]], [[Messalina]] and [[Julia the Elder]]—gained in their lifetime a reputation of extreme promiscuity. {{Quote|text= On the field of pleasure she [Empress Theodora] was never defeated. Often she would go picnicking with ten young men or more, in the flower of their strength and virility, and dallied with them all, the whole night through. … and even thus found no allayment of her craving … And though she flung wide three gates to the ambassadors of [[Cupid]], she lamented that nature had not similarly unlocked the straits of her bosom, that she might there have contrived a further welcome to his emissaries.| sign=[[Procopius]]|source=''Secret History''. [[Wikisource:The Secret History/Part 2/Chapter IX|Chapter IX]]: How Theodora, the most depraved of all courtesans, won his love}}
The [[Bible]] features many female personages identified as being promiscuous, among them the [[Whore of Babylon]], [[Jezebel|Princess Jezebel]], [[Thyatira|Prophetess Jezebel]], [[Gomer (wife of Hosea)|Gomer]], [[Rahab]], [[Salome]], and [[Zuleika (legendary)|Potiphar's unnamed wife]]. {{Quote|text= Yet she [Oholibah] became more and more promiscuous as she recalled the days of her youth, when she was a prostitute in Egypt. / There she lusted after her lovers, whose genitals were like those of donkeys and whose emission was like that of horses.| sign=[[The Bible]] ([[New International Version|NIV]])|source=[[The Book of Ezekiel]] [[Wikisource:Bible (King James)/Ezekiel/Chapter 23|XXIII]]:19-20}}
Female genital mutilation is found in many African and a few Asian societies.
The development of [[chastity belts]], apparently in the 14th century, proved handy to men worried about the prospect of their wives committing [[adultery]].<ref>Tannahill, Reay. ''Sex in history'' (1980). New York: Stein and Day. p.276.</ref>
=== Modern === [[File:Catherine II (Rotari type, GIM) by shakko.jpg|thumb|150px|Empress [[Catherine the Great]], a crucial figure at the time of the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]], is popularly remembered for [[Legends of Catherine the Great|her sexual promiscuity]].]]
Many cultures have historically laid much restriction on sexuality, most emphatically against immoderate expression of sexuality by women. In contrast, some recent ethical philosophies—both secular (coming from [[individualism]] and [[sex-positive feminism]]) and religious (e.g., [[Wicca]], [[Thelema]], [[LaVeyan Satanism]])—either tolerate it or outright celebrate it. {{Quote|text= We believe that it is fundamentally a radical political act to deprivatize sex. So much oppression in our culture is based on shame about sex: the oppression of women, of cultural minorities, oppression in the name of the (presumably asexual) family, oppression of sexual minorities. We are all oppressed. We have all been taught, one way or another, that our desires, our bodies, our sexualities, are shameful. What better way to defeat oppression than to get together in communities and celebrate the wonders of sex?| sign=[[Dossie Easton]], [[Catherine Liszt]]|source=''[[The Ethical Slut]]''. Chapter XXII: Group Sex, Public Sex, Orgies…}}
Public opinion has fluctuated over the centuries, with such downturns as [[Puritan#Family life|New England Puritanism]] (1630—1660) and the [[Victorian era]] (1837—1901), when [[hypersexuality]] was often treated as an exclusively female disorder, diagnosed on the grounds of as little as masturbation alone (see [[Hypersexuality#Nymphomania in the Victorian age|here]]).<ref name=Frick>{{cite web|last=Frick |first=Katie L. |title=Women's Mental Illness: A Response to Oppression |url=http://www.cwrl.utexas.edu/~ulrich/femhist/madness.shtml#spinsters |publisher=[[University of Texas at Austin]] |accessdate=26 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330061024/http://www.cwrl.utexas.edu/~ulrich/femhist/madness.shtml |archivedate=30 March 2010 |year=2002}}</ref> Up until the late 20th century, women could be incarcerated for promiscuous behavior in so-called [[Magdalene asylum]]s, the last of which was closed in Ireland in 1996.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/25/world/europe/25iht-abuse25.html?_r=3 |title=Irish Church's Forgotten Victims Take Case to U.N. |last=Ryan |first=Carol |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=May 25, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-archer.co.uk/history/magdalene1.htm |title=The Magdalene Laundry |author=Alison Roberts |year=2003 |publisher=The-archer.co.uk |accessdate=2014-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Institutionalised |author=Garth Toyntanen |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-9558501-0-3 |page=4}}</ref> From 1897 to 1958, [[Ontario]] used the [[Velma Demerson|Female Refuges Act]] to incarcerate women felt to be "incorrigible".
Following the [[Industrial Revolution]] (1760~1840), as Western countries underwent [[industrialization]] and [[urbanization]], education and employment opportunities were increasing for women. This environment gave rise in the late 19th century to the feminist ideal called "the [[New Woman]]"—a personification of female economic, sexual and other autonomy—which had a profound influence on feminism well into the 20th century. It wasn't until the [[Married Women's Property Act 1882]] that female British citizens were no longer legally compelled, upon marriage, to transfer all their property to their husbands. The [[Women's Movement]] was closely [[Free love#Free love and the women's movement|allied]] with the [[free love]] movement, whose advocates had a strong belief that a woman ought to be herself [[Self-ownership|sovereign over her body]].
{{Quote|text=Laws against adultery [were] [[Adultery#Historical context|based]] upon the idea that woman is a chattel, so that to make love to a married woman is to deprive the husband of her services. It is the frankest and most crass statement of a slave-situation. To us, every woman … has … an absolute right to travel in her own orbit. There is no reason why she should not be the ideal [[Wiktionary:hausfrau|hausfrau]], if that chance to be her will. But society has no right to insist upon that standard. It was, for practical reasons, almost necessary to set up such taboos in small communities, savage tribes, where the wife was nothing but a general servant, where the safety of the people depended upon a high birth-rate. But to-day woman is economically independent, becomes more so every year. The result is that she instantly asserts her right to have as many or as few men or babies as she wants or can get; and she defies the world to interfere with her. More power to her!| sign=[[Aleister Crowley]]|source=''[[The Law is for All]]'', the New Comment 1:41}}
The [[Roaring Twenties]] have been described as "a time when gin was the national drink and sex the national obsession."<ref name="obituary">{{cite news|title=Scott Fitzgerald, Author, Dies at 44 |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=December 23, 1940 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/bday/0924.html |accessdate=December 21, 2012 |type=Obituary}}</ref> Popular at that time was a female subculture called "[[flappers]]", who flouted social and sexual norms and were considered a significant challenge to Victorian [[gender roles]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://history1900s.about.com/od/1920s/a/flappers.htm |title=Flappers in the Roaring Twenties |first=Jennifer |last=Rosenberg |accessdate=2010-04-25 |publisher=[[About.com]]}}</ref> But these sentiments were then overshadowed by the [[Great Depression]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Paul N. Hehn |title=A Low Dishonest Decade: The Great Powers, Eastern Europe, And the Economic Origins of World War II, 1930–1941 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nOALhEZkYDkC&pg=PA12 |year=2005 |publisher=Continuum |page=12 |isbn=978-0-8264-1761-9}}</ref> Despite this, the 1925 silent film ''[[The Red Kimono]]'', sympathetic toward its promiscuous protagonist, was subject to severe censorship,<ref name=Campbell>{{cite web|last=Campbell |first=Russell |title="Fallen woman" prostitute narratives in the cinema |url=http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/firstrelease/fr1199/rcfr8b.htm |publisher=LaTrobe University |accessdate=2011-12-01 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308080040/http://www.latrobe.edu.au/screeningthepast/firstrelease/fr1199/rcfr8b.htm |archivedate=8 March 2011}}</ref> and led to a landmark legal case, ''[[Melvin v. Reid]]''.
The 1950s in America is stereotyped to have been sexually repressed, though not as severely as the Victorian era. Female promiscuity in particular became substantially more accepted in [[Western world|Western]] culture after the [[sexual revolution]] of the 1960s, which resonated with the [[hippie movement]]. It also became more prevalent a theme in [[mass media]], including cinema (e.g., ''[[Sex and the City (film)|Sex and the City]]'') and music (e.g., ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]'' by [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]).
[[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] has been at the forefront of the [[gender neutrality|gender neutrality]] movement in terms of promiscuity since becoming a globally recognized entertainer in the 1980’s. In addition to her sexually explicit song lyrics and occasional nude self exposures during live performances and almost being arrested in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada, on May 29, 1990 for simulating masturbation in public <ref>http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6582939/madonna-masturbation-like-a-virgin-controversy-toronto-anniversary</ref>, her book [[Sex (book)|Sex]] released on Oct 21, 1992 was a commercially successful nude pictorial of her and various famous celebrities engaging in scenes of purported promiscuity, further enhancing her vision of gender equality in this regard.
There has been an increase in awareness of [[discrimination]] on grounds of promiscuity—apparent or actual—which at least since year 2010 has been called ''[[slut shaming]]''.<ref name="Post">{{cite news|last=Lang |first=Nico |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/nico-lang/trampires-why-the-slut-sh_b_1850940.html |title=‘Trampire:’ Why the Public Slut Shaming of Kristen Stewart Matters for Young Women |newspaper=Huffington Post |date=April 9, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Times">{{cite news|last=Slattery |first=Laura |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/features/2012/1218/1224327955336.html |title=The year of slut-shaming, creepshots, Malala and more |newspaper=Irish Times |date=December 18, 2012}}</ref> On April 3, 2011,<ref>{{cite web|title=SlutWalk Toronto: What |url=http://www.slutwalktoronto.com/about/what |accessdate=19 October 2011}}</ref> the [[SlutWalk]] movement—protesting against explaining or excusing [[rape]] by referring to any aspect of a woman's [[Human physical appearance|appearance]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thespec.com/news/canada/article/511501--slut-walk-crowded |title=‘Slut walk’ crowded |publisher=TheSpec |date=2011-04-04 |accessdate=2011-05-29}}</ref> and later, by extension, calling for sexual freedom in general—began in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada, and went on to spread throughout the world.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/victoria/a-rally-to-find-the-slut-in-everyone-20110528-1f9w3.html |title=‘A Rally to find the slut in everyone’ |publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=2011-05-29 |accessdate=2011-05-30}}</ref>

On April 20, 2010, [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] Islamic cleric Hojatoleslam Kazem Sedighi provoked transnational ridicule by blaming promiscuous women for causing earthquakes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8631775.stm |publisher=BBC |title=Iranian cleric blames quakes on promiscuous women |date=20 April 2010 |accessdate=2014-01-21}}</ref> Six days later, on the 26th of April, the American [[Boobquake]] gathering, organized by the [[blog]]ger Jennifer McCreight and attended by 200,000 participants,<ref name=TorontoStar>{{cite news|title=Women strut their stuff for Boobquake |author=Black, Debra |newspaper=Toronto Star |date=26 April 2010 |url=https://www.thestar.com/living/article/800820--women-strut-their-stuff-for-boobquake}}</ref><ref name=HeraldDeParis>{{cite news|title=Coup de Ta-Tas: Cleric’s comment ignites skin-bearing backlash |author=Brownrigg, Kirsten |newspaper=Herald de Paris |date=27 April 2010 |accessdate=28 April 2010 |url=http://www.heralddeparis.com/coup-de-ta-tas-cleric%E2%80%99s-comment-ignites-skin-bearing-backlash/85379}}</ref> was held in response to it.
Japan wasn't as soon to be reached by the [[sexual revolution]], originating in the American 1960s. The documentary ''Japan — Female Sexuality'' touched on the subject from a 1990s perspective, and reported the trend to be increasing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journeyman.tv/9687/short-films/female-sexuality.html |title=Japan — Female Sexuality |newspaper=ABC Australia |date=1 May 1994}}</ref>
Although [[polygyny]] is more common, some tribal societies are traditionally [[polyandrous]].
=== Religious === {{Main|Fornication}}
== Statistics ==
The use of [[demographical]] methods in [[sexological]] research was pioneered by the American zoologist [[Alfred Kinsey]], who published two books—''Sexual Behavior in the Human Male'' (1948) and ''Sexual Behavior in the Human Female'' (1953)—collectively known as the [[Kinsey Reports]]. The reports defied the expectations of the public and paved the way for the [[sexual revolution]] of the 1960s.
Accurately assessing people's sexual behavior is difficult, since there are strong social and personal motivations, depending on social [[Social control|sanctions]] and [[taboo]]s, for either minimizing or exaggerating reported sexual activity. Women tend to undervalue the number of their sex partners whereas men tend to overestimate the number of theirs.{{Citation needed|date=May 2014}}
In a 1994 study in the United States, almost all married heterosexual women reported having sexual contact only with their husbands, and unmarried women almost always reported having no more than one sexual partner in the past three months. [[Lesbian]]s who had a long-term partner reported having fewer outside partners than heterosexual women.<ref name="nejm">{{cite journal|doi=10.1056/NEJM199410063311407 |last1=Friedman |first1=RC |last2=Downey |first2=JI |year=1994 |title=Homosexuality |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |publisher=Massachusetts Medical Society |volume=331 |issue=October 6, 1994, Number 14 |pages=923–930 |url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/full/331/14/923#R10 |pmid=8078554}}</ref> More recent research, however, contradicts the assertion that heterosexual women are largely [[monogamous]]. A 2002 study estimated that 45% to 55% of married heterosexual women engage in sexual relationships outside their marriage.<ref name="Atwood">{{cite journal|last=Atwood |first=JD |last2=Schwartz |first2=L |title=Cyber-Sex The New Affair Treatment Considerations |journal=Journal of Couple & Relationship Therapy: Innovations in Clinical and Educational Interventions |year=2002 |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=37–56 |doi=10.1300/J398v01n03_03}}</ref> While the estimates for heterosexual males in the same study were greater (50%–60%), the data indicates that a significant portion of married heterosexual women have or have had sexual partners other than their spouse as well.<ref name="Atwood" />
One international study found women to be more variable than men in their sex drive.<ref name="Lippa2009" /> International measurements of promiscuity are inconsistent from study to study, varying by the methodology used. Due to practical reason—the inability to survey a country's entire population—all studies of this class are [[Inductive reasoning|inductive]], generalizing about the general population based on assessments of sample groups supposed to be representative of the larger population being studied.
For example, in a non-scientific study conducted by the condom-making company [[Durex]], British women reported fewer partners than British men, while the only country where women reported more sex partners than men did was [[New Zealand]] (20.4 versus 16.8), which was also the country where women reported more sex partners than did women from all other countries surveyed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2007/10/13/1191696214489.html |title=New Zealand women most promiscuous |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=October 13, 2007}}</ref> To further complicate matters, a well-known study in general sociosexuality that surveyed 14,059 people across 48 countries, placed New Zealand, which came right before [[Slovenia]], second to [[Finland]]; the [[United States]], in the unisex scores of the same study, came in 22nd.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schmitt |first=David |title=Sociosexuality from Argentina to Zimbabwe: a 48-nation study of sex, culture, and strategies of human mating |journal=The Behavioral and Brain Sciences |volume=28 |pages=247–75; discussion 275–311 |year=2005 |pmid=16201459 |issue=2 |url=http://psych.mcmaster.ca/dalywilson/commentary_schmitt.pdf |doi=10.1017/S0140525X05000051 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226234624/http://psych.mcmaster.ca/dalywilson/commentary_schmitt.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-26 |df= }}</ref>
== Terminology == [[File:Order-cuckoldry-ca1815-French-satire.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Ca. 1815 French satire on [[cuckoldry]], which shows both men and women wearing horns.]] Sexual relations with multiple males are termed ''[[polyandry]]''. It has a more specific meaning in zoology, where it refers to a type of [[mating system]], and in anthropology, where it refers to a type of [[marriage]]. Sexual relations with multiple females are termed ''[[polygyny]]'', but in zoology it can only be applied to heterosexual relations. [[Polyamory]] is sometimes defined as [[non-monogamy]] with consent of all parties involved, if within or without [[committed relationship]]s. Attitudinal differences concerning sex outside committed relationships are referred to under the term ''[[sociosexual orientation]]'' or simply ''sociosexuality''.
Since at least 1450, the word ''[[slut]]'' has been used, often pejoratively, to describe a sexually promiscuous woman.<ref>{{OEtymD|slut}}</ref> In and before the [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] and [[Jacobean era]]s, terms like "strumpet" and "whore" were used to describe women deemed promiscuous, as seen for example in [[John Webster]]'s 1612 play ''[[The White Devil]]''.
Discrimination targeting individuals, specifically women, for sexual behavior deemed excessive, has been referred to, since at least spring of 2010, with the [[neologism]] ''[[slut shaming]]'' (also hyphenated, as ''slut-shaming'').<ref name="Post" /><ref name="Times" />
''[[Cuckold]] fetish'' is colloquial for a [[paraphilia]] in which sexual gratification is gained from maintenance or observation of sexual relations by a woman with a man or a number of men besides her husband, boyfriend or long-term male sex partner.
The popular slang ''[[Cougar (slang)|cougar]]'' refers to a woman who seeks sexual relations with considerably younger men.
The term ''[[fallen woman]]'' was used to describe a woman who has "lost her innocence", and fallen from the grace of God. In [[Victorian era|Victorian]] Britain especially, the meaning came to be closely associated with the "loss or surrender of a woman's chastity". Its use was an expression of the belief that to be socially and morally acceptable a women's sexuality and experience should be entirely restricted to marriage, and that she should also be under the supervision and care of an authoritative man.

:''For the 2017 film adaptation, see [[First They Killed My Father (film)]].'' {{Infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = First They Killed My Father | title_orig = | translator = | image = ftkmf.jpg | image_size = 175px | caption = US edition paperback cover | author = [[Loung Ung]] | cover_artist = [[Loung Ung]], Mary Schuck | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Memoir]] | publisher = [[HarperCollins]] | release_date = 2000 | media_type = Print ([[paperback]]) | pages = 238 p. | isbn = 0-06-093138-8 | oclc = 45831904 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''First They Killed My Father: A Daughter of Cambodia Remembers''''' is a 2000 non-fiction book written by [[Loung Ung]], a [[Cambodia]]n author and childhood survivor of [[Democratic Kampuchea]]. It is her personal account of her experiences during the [[Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia|communist years]].
Until the age of five, Loung Ung lived in Phnom Penh, one of seven children of a high-ranking government official. She was a precocious child who loved the open city markets, fried crickets, chicken fights and sassing her parents. While her beautiful mother worried that Loung was a troublemaker—that she stomped around like a thirsty cow—her beloved father knew Loung was a clever girl.
When [[Pol Pot]]'s [[Khmer Rouge]] army [[Cambodian Civil War#Fall of Phnom Penh|stormed into Phnom Penh]] in April 1975, Ung's family fled their home and moved from village to village to hide their identity, their education, their former life of privilege. Eventually, the family dispersed in order to survive. Because Loung was resilient and determined, she trained as a child soldier in a work camp for orphans whilst other siblings were sent to labour camps. As the [[Cambodian–Vietnamese War#Invasion of Kampuchea|Vietnamese penetrated Cambodia]], destroyed the Khmer Rouge, the surviving siblings were slowly reunited. Bolstered by the shocking bravery of one brother, the vision of the others and sustained by her sister's gentle kindness amid brutality, Loung forged herself a new life.<ref>{{cite web|title=First They Killed My Father (Ung)|url=http://www.litlovers.com/reading-guides/14-non-fiction/331-first-they-killed-my-father-ung|website=LitLovers|accessdate=9 April 2015}}</ref>
The book was criticized by Bunkong Tuon for being inaccurate and, therefore, not being useful for historical research by Sody Lay, an American Cambodian reviewer. Reflecting on this negative review, Bunkong Tuon considers Sody Lay's review right and, at the same time, defends the memoirs as an emotional truth instead of a historical truth.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tuon |first1=B. |title=Inaccuracy and Testimonial Literature: The Case of Loung Ung's First They Killed My Father: A Daughter of Cambodia Remembers |journal=MELUS: Multi-Ethnic Literature of the United States |date=5 June 2013 |volume=38 |issue=3 |pages=107–125 |doi=10.1093/melus/mlt032}}</ref>
== Film adaptation == {{main|First They Killed My Father (film)}} The book has been adapted into [[First They Killed My Father (film)|a movie]] that was produced and directed by [[Angelina Jolie]]. The film premiered on February 18, 2017 in Siem Reap, Cambodia.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Angelina Jolie Pitt to Direct Netflix Original Film 'First They Killed My Father'|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2015/07/24/angelina-jolie-pitt-to-direct-netflix-original-film-first-they-killed-my-father/|journal=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=25 July 2015}}</ref>
"The heart of it is Loung's story", Jolie states on the film. "It's the story of a war through the eyes of a child, but it is also the story of a country". To construct an accurate portrait of the genocide and war, Jolie used only Cambodian actors who speak their native language, Khmer. She gathered hundreds of survivors and their children to re-create their stories. The movie was filmed in Cambodia.

{{Infobox award | name = Foot in Mouth Award | description = "a baffling comment by a public figure." | presenter = [[Plain English Campaign]] | country = United Kingdom | year = 1993 | year2 = | holder = [[Jacob Rees-Mogg]] (2017) | website = [http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/awards/foot-in-mouth-award.html plainenglish.co.uk] }} The '''Foot in Mouth Award''' is presented each year by the [[Plain English Campaign]] for "a baffling comment by a public figure".<ref name="thevine">{{cite news|url=http://www.thevine.com.au/entertainment/top10/top-10-weirdest-awards-ceremonies/ |title=Top 10 weirdest awards ceremonies |work=TheVine.com.au |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]] |location=Sydney |date=16 February 2012 |accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> The award was first made in 1993, when it was given to [[Ted Dexter]], the chairman of selectors for the [[England cricket team]]. It was awarded again the following year, and, after a two-year break, annually from 1997.<ref name="past"/>
The Plain English Campaign was set up in 1979 when the founder, [[Chrissie Maher]], shredded hundreds of jargon-filled forms and documents in [[Parliament Square]], London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ljmu.ac.uk/Graduation/114808.htm |title=Chrissie Maher |publisher=[[Liverpool John Moores University]] |last=Grant |first=Neil |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=18 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022175452/http://www.ljmu.ac.uk/Graduation/114808.htm |archivedate=22 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> The group made their first awards the next year, rewarding those organisations that used plain English, and highlighting those that did not.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/awards/about-the-awards.html |title=About the awards |publisher=Plain English Campaign |accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> Although the Foot in Mouth award was first made in 1993, a specific acknowledgment was made to a comment by [[Dan Quayle]], [[Vice President of the United States]] in 1991.<ref name="past"/>
The award has been presented 20 times, and only [[Rhodri Morgan]] and [[Boris Johnson]] have received it more than once. The Welsh politician won in both 1998 and 2005, and made a light-hearted response to his second win, claiming that the first award had "made [his] name."<ref name="past"/> Politicians have been recipients of the award more times than any other group of people, collecting it on 14 occasions; people from the world of sport have won four times. The 43rd President of the United States, [[George W. Bush]], received the award in 2008, with the subtitle "Lifetime Achievement Award", given not for a single quote, but for his continued "services to gobbledygook".<ref name="past"/>
==Winners== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ Foot in Mouth award winners |- ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" width="140px"| Recipient ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Image ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Rationale ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Ref |- | 1991 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Dan|Quayle}} | [[File:Dan Quayle crop.jpg|100px|Dan Quayle|alt=Dan Quayle]] | Although the Foot in Mouth award was not introduced until 1993, the [[Vice President of the United States]], Dan Quayle received a special mention during the 1991 awards for his tent metaphor: "We offer the party as a big tent. How we do that [recognise the [[big tent]] philosophy] with the platform, the preamble to the platform or whatnot, that remains to be seen. But that message will have to be articulated with great clarity." | <ref name="past"/> |- | 1993 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Ted|Dexter}} | – | Dexter, a senior figure in the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]], won the inaugural award for trying to explain a loss by the [[England cricket team]] by saying: "Maybe we are in the wrong sign. Maybe Venus is in the wrong juxtaposition with something else. I don't know." | <ref name="past"/> |- | 1994 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Gordon|Brown}} | [[File:Gordon Brown smiles.jpg|100px|Gordon Brown|alt=Gordon Brown]] | As the [[Shadow Chancellor of the Exchequer]], Brown gave a speech on "New Economics" full of baffling jargon such as; "the growth of post neo-classical [[endogenous growth theory]]" and "debate over the meaning and implications of competitiveness at the level of individuals, the firm or the nation and the role of government in fashioning modern industrial policies which focus on nurturing competitiveness." | <ref name="past"/> |- | 1997 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Nick|Underwood|nolink=1}} | – | A member of the ''[[Teletubbies]]'' marketing department, Underwood won the award for his explanation that; "in life, there are all colours and the Teletubbies are a reflection of that. There are no nationalities in the ''Teletubbies'' – they are techno-babies, but they are supposed to reflect life in that sense." | <ref name="past"/> |- | 1998 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Rhodri|Morgan}} | [[File:Rhodri Morgan.jpg|100px|Rhodri Morgan|alt=Rhodri Morgan]] | Rhodri Morgan, the [[First Minister of Wales]], confused interviewer [[Jeremy Paxman]] when asked if he would like to be leader of the [[National Assembly for Wales|Welsh Assembly]], by responding: "Does a one-legged duck swim in circles?" | <ref name="rhodri">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/4523636.stm |title=Morgan's gobbledegook award No. 2 |work=[[BBC News]] |date=13 December 2005 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref>
|- | 1999 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Glenn|Hoddle}} | [[File:Glenn Hoddle2.jpg|100px|Glenn Hoddle|alt=Glenn Hoddle]] | The [[England national football team manager|England football manager]] won the award for his response to a question about his earlier comments that disabled people were born that way because they were being punished for sins in former lives: "I do not believe that. At this moment in time, if that changes in years to come I don't know, but what happens here today and changes as we go along that is part of life's learning and part of your inner beliefs. But at this moment in time I did not say them things and at the end of the day I want to put that on record because it has hurt people." | <ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/dec/08/5 |title=Prescott's prize for bad language |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |location=London |date=8 December 1999 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2000 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Alicia|Silverstone}} | [[File:Alicia Silverstone, Festival of Books.jpg|100px|Alicia Silverstone|alt=Alicia Silverstone]] | The American actress, star of ''[[Clueless (film)|Clueless]]'', was awarded for her comment: "I think that ''Clueless'' was very deep. I think it was deep in the way that it was very light. I think lightness has to come from a very deep place if it's true lightness." | <ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1057660.stm |title=Alicia leaves us Clueless |work=[[BBC News]] |date=6 December 2000 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2001 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Tracey|Emin}} | [[File:Tracey Emin 1-cropped.jpg|100px|Tracey Emin|alt=Tracey Emin]] | Artist Tracey Emin won the award for her comment: "When it comes to words I have a uniqueness that I find almost impossible in terms of art – and it's my words that actually make my art quite unique." | <ref name="gere">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/dec/05/film.filmnews |title=Gere stumbles across award |last=Ezard |first=John |work=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]] |location=London |date=5 December 2002 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref>
|- | 2002 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Richard|Gere}} | [[File:Richardgere.jpg|100px|Richard Gere|alt=Richard Gere]] | The American actor was presented with the award for his philosophical comment: "I know who I am. No one else knows who I am. If I was a giraffe and somebody said I was a snake, I'd think 'No, actually I am a giraffe." | <ref name="gere"/> |- | 2003 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Donald|Rumsfeld}} | [[File:Donald Rumsfeld Defenselink.jpg|100px|Donald Rumsfeld|alt=Donald Rumsfeld]] | For his overuse of the word "know" during a press briefing given as [[United States Secretary of Defense]]: "Reports that say that something hasn't happened are always interesting to me, because as we know, [[there are known knowns]]; there are things we know we know. We also know there are known unknowns; that is to say we know there are some things we do not know. But there are also unknown unknowns — the ones we don't know we don't know." | <ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/3254852.stm |title=Rum remark wins Rumsfeld an award |work=[[BBC News]] |date=2 December 2003 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2004 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Boris|Johnson}} | [[File:Boris Johnson -opening bell at NASDAQ-14Sept2009-3c cropped.jpg|100px|Boris Johnson|alt=Boris Johnson]] | During the [[BBC]]'s light-hearted news quiz show ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] politician Johnson commented, "I could not fail to disagree with you less." | <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-329474/Bumbling-Boris-lands-Foot-Mouth-award.html |title=Bumbling Boris lands Foot in Mouth award |work=[[Daily Mail]] |publisher=[[Daily Mail and General Trust]] |location=London |date=3 December 2004 |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2005 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Rhodri|Morgan}} | [[File:Rhodri Morgan.jpg|100px|Rhodri Morgan|alt=Rhodri Morgan]] | Welsh politician Rhodri Morgan's second award was given for a quote made during a debate on policing; "The only thing which isn't up for grabs is no change and I think it's fair to say, it's all to play for, except for no change." | <ref name="rhodri"/> |- | 2006 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Naomi|Campbell}} | [[File:Naomi Campbell Cannes cropped.jpg|100px|Naomi Campbell|alt=Naomi Campbell]] | The English [[supermodel]] picked up the award for saying, "I love England, especially the food. There's nothing I like more than a lovely bowl of pasta." | <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2006/12/12/naomis-super-gaffe |title=Naomi's Super Gaffe |last=Jones |first=Dolly |work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast Publications|Condé Nast]] |location=New York |date=12 December 2006 |accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2007 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Steve|McClaren}} | [[File:Steve McClaren 2012 1.jpg|100px|Steve McClaren|alt=Steve McClaren]] | For describing footballer [[Wayne Rooney]]: "He is inexperienced, but he's experienced in terms of what he's been through", when talking to [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] in his role as [[England national football team manager|England manager]]. | <ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/12/11/us-english-idUSL117878120071211 |title=George Bush loses close run for 'Foot in Mouth' |last=Majendie |first=Paul |agency=Reuters |date=11 December 2007 |accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2008 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|George W.|Bush}} | [[File:George-W-Bush.jpeg|100px|George W. Bush|alt=George W. Bush]] | Bush's award was made during his final year in office as [[President of the United States]]. Entitled a "Lifetime Achievement Award", it was given for his "services to gobbledygook". His gaffes were described as covering a large number of topics, and included comments such as "I know what I believe. I will continue to articulate what I believe and what I believe – I believe what I believe is right", and, "I hope you leave here and walk out and say, 'what did he say?'" | <ref name="past">{{cite web |url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/awards/foot-in-mouth-award/foot-in-mouth-winners.html |title=Past winners |publisher=Plain English Campaign |accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2008-12-09/news/17911550_1_president-bush-watchdog-conferences |title=President Bush's abuse of English language gets Foot in Mouth award |last=Boyle |first=Christina |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |publisher=Daily News, L.P. |location=New York |date=9 December 2008 |accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2009 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Peter|Mandelson|alt=Peter Mandelson}} | [[File:Lord Mandelson Allan Warren.JPG|100px|Peter Mandelson]] | Awarded for the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] politician's remark on the investigation into the [[United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal]]; "Perhaps we need not more people looking round more corners but the same people looking round more corners more thoroughly to avoid the small things detracting from the big things the Prime Minister is getting right." | <ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/8400350.stm |title=Mandelson wins award for political 'gobbledegook' |work=[[BBC News]] |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2010 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Jamie|Redknapp}} | [[File:Redknapp, Jamie (crop).jpg|100px|Jamie Redknapp|alt=Jamie Redknapp]] | Repeated misuse of the word "literally" made during his career as a sports commentator, in such quotes as: "These balls now – they literally explode off your feet." | <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1337341/Boris-Johnson-Jamie-Redknapp-shamed-poor-use-English.html |title=Boris Johnson and Jamie Redknapp shamed over poor use of English |work=[[Daily Mail]] |publisher=[[Daily Mail and General Trust]] |location=London |date=10 December 2010 |author=Daily Mail Reporter |accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2011 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Silvio|Berlusconi}} | [[File:Berlusconi-2010-1.jpg|100px|alt=Silvio Berlusconi|Silvio Berlusconi]] | The former [[Prime Minister of Italy|Italian Prime Minister]] received the award for comments such as "I am pretty often faithful", when talking about fidelity in 2006, and describing [[Barack Obama]] in 2008 as being "Handsome, young and also suntanned". | <ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/topics/weather/8944144/Met-Office-wins-award-for-bad-English-for-using-phrase-a-rash-of-beefy-showers.html |title=Met Office wins award for bad English for using phrase 'a rash of beefy showers' |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]] |location=London |last=Bloxham |first=Andy |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.corpcommsmagazine.co.uk/news/1971-plain-english-awards |title=Plain English Awards |publisher=CorpComms |last=Humphris |first=Rachel |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=18 September 2012}}</ref> |- | 2012 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Mitt|Romney}} | [[File:Mitt Romney.jpg|100px|alt=Mitt Romney|Mitt Romney]] | [[2012 U.S. Presidential election|U.S. Presidential candidate]] Mitt Romney received the award for making gaffes on the domestic front: "I like being able to fire people who provide services to me"; on the international stage, for example, regarding the [[2012 London Olympics|London Olympics]]: "There are a few things that were disconcerting. The stories about the private security firm not having enough people, the supposed strike of the immigration and customs officials – that obviously is not something which is encouraging"; and generally incomprehensible comments such as "I believe in an America where millions of Americans believe in an America that's the America millions of Americans believe in. That's the America I love." | <ref>{{cite web|title=2012 Foot in Mouth award winner|url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/awards/foot-in-mouth-award.html|work=Plain English Campaign|accessdate=11 February 2013}}</ref> |- | 2013 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Godfrey|Bloom}} | [[File:Godfrey Bloom.jpg|100px|alt=Godfrey Bloom|Godfrey Bloom]] | [[United Kingdom Independence Party]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] Godfrey Bloom, who sits in the body as an Independent, received the award after making a series of controversial statements in 2013, including describing countries that receive foreign aid from the UK as "[[Bongo Bongo Land]]", saying that women don't "clean behind the fridge enough", jokingly referring to female members of an audience as "sluts" and assaulting one journalist and threatening another. A spokesman called him "an overwhelming choice" who "could easily have won this award on at least two other occasions... [he's] a wince-inducing gaffe machine and we could fill a page or two with his ill-advised quotes from 2013 alone." | <ref name="BBC News">{{cite web|title=Foot in mouth gong for Godfrey Bloom, Yorkshire and Humber MEP|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-25215093|work=BBC News|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="2013 Foot in Mouth award winner">{{cite web|title=2013 Foot in Mouth award winner|url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/campaigning/awards/2013-awards/foot-in-mouth-award.html|work=Plain English Campaign|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> |- |2014 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Russell|Brand}} | [[File:Russell Brand Arthur Premier mike.jpg|100px|alt=Russell Brand|Russell Brand]] |The Plain English Campaign said that Brand was "out on his own" among contenders for the title, adding: "While we admire Russell's determination to open up a debate about democracy and the dire state of the world, we struggle to make sense of most of his comments."
Among Brand's quotes singled out by the campaign as award-winners were: "The internal mayhem I'm feeling is spilling out everywhere. I loved it, and felt very connected to activism - particularly activism that feels loaded with potential. Not the oppositional activism that seems like there's a stasis around it - earnestly sincere, but a monolith equal to the establishment." |<ref>{{cite web|title=Russell Brand wins award for making the least sense of all|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/russell-brand-wins-award-for-making-the-least-sense-of-all-9900350.html|work=The Independent|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref> |- |2015 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Donald|Trump}} | [[File:Donald Trump August 19, 2015 3 by 2.jpg|100px|alt=Donald Trump|Donald Trump]] |Donald Trump was at the time campaigning for the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|Republican nomination]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 US presidential election]]. The Plain English Campaign said that Trump was "unrivalled". In particular the campaign cited his remarks on Mexican immigrants: "They're bringing drugs. They're bringing crime. They're rapists. And some, I assume, are good people." It also cited his remarks on [[John McCain]]: "He’s not a war hero. He was a war hero because he was captured. I like people who weren’t captured." |<ref>{{cite web|title=Foot in Mouth award 2015|url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/campaigning/awards/2015-awards/foot-in-mouth-award.html}}</ref> |- | 2016 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Boris|Johnson}} | [[File:Boris Johnson -opening bell at NASDAQ-14Sept2009-3c cropped.jpg|100px|Boris Johnson|alt=Boris Johnson]] |Boris is regularly a contender for the Foot in Mouth Award and this year proved no exception. This, Boris’s second win, was secured by the unsinkable: "Brexit means Brexit and we’re going to make a Titanic success of it." |<ref>{{cite web|title=Foot in Mouth award 2016|url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/campaigning/awards/2016-awards/foot-in-mouth-award.html}}</ref> |- | 2017 ! scope="row" | {{sortname|Jacob|Rees-Mogg}} | [[File:Jacobreesmogg.JPG|100px|Jacobreesmogg]] |Jacob Rees-Mogg, elbowing aside regular Foot in Mouth favourites Donald Trump and Boris Johnson, described food banks as "rather uplifting". Most people consider food banks deeply worrying symptoms of the widening gulf between rich and poor. Rees-Mogg, MP for North East Somerset, seemed to delight in working families relying on charity to survive. |<ref>{{cite web|title=Foot in Mouth award 2017|url=http://www.plainenglish.co.uk/files/issue88.pdf}}</ref> |}
